text: The food was delish! Spicy, so I would request Mild next time. Yellow curry outstanding and lettuce wraps so unique

They do NOT accept Credit cards. Funny, they had an icon of Visa card on their front glass window. What kind of confusion is this Now? Moreover, they got shut down because of WHAT? Oh Oh! Tasty food but small portions is exactly what I needed there at Opart Thai House. Unfortunately I wont be going there anymore because they do not accept credit cards.

This place is so authentic I can't even explain it. My favorite dishes are pad see eiw and tiger cry! I am giving this place 4 out of 5 because I have yet to try anything new here in forever lol. I will be back to try it all! It also is very reasonably priced for the amount of food you are getting. I have tried MANY Thai places in Chicago and this is in the top 3 for sure !

The food was phenomenal. We usually go to Tom Lee's (next door) for Asian food, but we finally popped in here and HOLY SMOKES Y'ALL. We were blown away by the food. And the portion sizes. Definitely a hidden gem in the neighborhood, right below the Western train tracks up in Lincoln Square. Get the potstickers! Loved it. Killer playlist too!  The wait staff was super friendly and timely.
Loved the chicken pad Thai and green curry with coconut milk. Even through the delivery the food stayed fresh and amazing!

This place is horrible! Our food came out 5 minutes after ordering.The food was either sweet or sour, the papaya salad tasted like carrots and vinegar. Tom yum soup tastes like 100% lemonade with floating shrimps and the crab rangoons were soggy. I walked in with 6 hungry friends 1.45 hr before closing. As we walked in we were stared by a young lady with her arms crossed who did not say a word. So rude! While we were eating the staff members stood 8 feet away from us arms crossed and stared at us! How awkward was that. We minded our own business did not say much just wanting to hurry and finish ASAP to get the heck out. I could not have survived staying any longer at this point I was so annoyed. They need new staff, the current ones just dont care for the business maybe because the 20% gratuity was already included in the bill... pfft figures.  We were there for a total of 40minutes. We ate and left and never ever ever returning, seriously the worse dining experience ever. the food is bad and so is the service.

I'll just leave this here  dnainfo.com/chicago/2017… "The restaurant's license was initially suspended May 16 when city inspectors observed a number of "high-risk" violations, including cockroaches crawling on the kitchen's walls and floors." Go to Royal Thai or Rainbow Thai - both are right down the street and much, much better.
Unfortunately, they were closed during a few weeks in May due to massive roach infestation. The food was always great to me but I can't get over that fact.

Opart's on Western is NOT closed! It is open and serving great food as always! I have been there twice in the last 4 days (today is Saturday, June 3) and am going again tomorrow! You need to check this place out!!! It has been the best for over 30 years and STILL IS!!!
Disappointed and disgusted at their health code violations. You will never see me here again
Nope, nope, nope. Not going here again, as is apparently nasty AF. The restaurant failed not one, but two inspections in a row. Stay away until they get new management.
Man oh man, I really liked this restaurant...but will never eat from there again...you just don't come back from 30 cock roaches in the food prep area...they seriously broke our trust...

Don't know if Opart is ever worth returning to.  The other location on Chicago Ave. gave an extreme case of food sickness/poison... For like three days. This Opart location has been extremely successful that there is no excuse to not have an over night cleaning crew.  After knowing about this new case at this location it clearly reflects the care of the leadership/ownership towards its customers.  Not a good look because what does it say over all?  If a successful restaurant cares about the customer, in a real way,  than this health hazard should not have ever taken place. It says a lot. Question is... What restaurant has similar or better "Tiger Cry"? This was the go to restaurant for Tiger Cry so what are the recommendations people!?

We have been going to Opart Thai for many, many years.   The menu is varied and the food is prepared well.  Often, we will go with a large group, which is great because everybody has more dishes to taste!   Favorite dishes include Tiger Cry, Khao Soy, and Pad Ped Pla Dook.  Bonus points for BYO and friendly staff.   Opart Thai has never disappointed.  As such, we will continue to be loyal customers.

I used to think this place had the best thai food in Chicago until the Dept of health inspections went there and found many cockroaches in the kitchen amongst other health violations. I will NEVER come here or to any of their other locations again. And after being shut by the City, they have the nerve to try to cover up by putting up a sign outside saying opart will be closed for maintenance. I'm absolutely DISGUSTED and will NEVER come here again or go to their other locations.

Oh dear.  You know I actually really liked the food from Opart and would stop by at least once a month for a Thai fix.  Their dishes were tasty.  However, after reading the article posted on DNA Info that they had their license suspended on May 16 for serious health code violations, I won't be coming back to this location or any of their other locations in the city EVER.   From the DNA Info article:  "City health inspectors wrote of observing numerous "high risk" violations, including more than 30 cockroaches in the kitchen prep area 'crawling on wall and shelvings above the kitchen prep sink and on cracked walls near the kitchen exposed handsink ... [and] on encrusted floors beneath the cooking woks,' among other areas."  Uh, they had me at 30 cockroaches crawling in the kitchen prep area.....yuck, yuck and yuck.

BEWARE temporarily closed for failing a health inspection. Over 30 cockroaches discovered in the food prep area. Hazardous foods being stored at the wrong temperatures. This place is a bad case of food poisoning waiting to happen!
Closed by the City due to a NASTY cockroach infestation including cockroaches all over kitchen and cooking areas. Yummy !!!! dnainfo.com/chicago/2017…
My go to delivery for Thai! Delicious! They have a spicy shrimp dish that's to die for!
Had my birthday dinner here, they were so great when we had to increase the number of guests and let us sit around for a while. Always good food and good service!

I've eaten here twice and I would say it was pretty enjoyable.  Dishes I tried: -Tom Yum Soup.  Only comes in a large size.  I thought the flavor was good, but it was lacking much substance.  It needs more vegetables! It was essentially a pot of broth. -Steamed Potstickers.  Comes with 5.  I thought the taste was very doughy.   -Whole Red Snapper.  This was a very tasty dish for 2 people to share.  It was sufficiently spicy and had a nice teriyaki flavor to it. -Pad See-Iew.  Ordered "very spicy" and it was hardly mild.  The dish did have good flavor, but portion is pretty small. -Gaeng Panang Curry: Ordered "spicy" and once again it was mild.   The flavor was good, but the portion is pretty tiny.  I got 8 pieces of shrimp, and the dish does not even come with rice.  So the total amount with 2 orders of rice and extra fee for shrimp was about $16.  It also comes with no vegetables- just sauce and 8 shrimp. I was a bit turned off when the waitress snuck from behind me and grabbed my entree and started walking away when I was still eating it!  She did not even ask if I was done.  I had to ask her to bring it back.    Overall, I think this place has good flavors but they are stingy with portion sizes, no rice with entree, and they do NOT listen to your request for spiciness.  Why give us 4 options if you are going to cook it mild anyway?

Excellent thai food! The Tiger Cry is the best I've ever had.  The chicken wonton soup is amazing! Try it with extra greens. The gaeng gari curry and green curry are also delicious. The service is great. Deliveries are on time and always correct.
Service was slow, waitress was uninterested, fried rice was wet and flavorless and certainly not fried. Seafood tasted dangerously rubbery. Not coming here again.

I ordered via the Yelp app, and was given a deliver time. Well needless to say that time came & went so I called the restaurant. I spoke with a nice gal who looked up my order and she seemed puzzled because I was told that the driver had left over 10 minutes prior.  My order arrived 30 minutes passed my the stated delivery time. I was given a $10 credit off of my next order, but I don't know if I will ever use it based on my experience. Also I added 2 cans of soda to my order, well guess what it was delivered warm, not a chill anywhere near it. Now you might say, well hey, just go to the fridge & get some ice.  Problem with that, I was at my office, no freezer. The order wasn't placed at a busy time either, it was placed at 8:45 at night. The food was just ok. Chicken Satay & Chicken Pad Thai. I usually only order pizza for deliver, but I had a taste for Thai. I should stick to pizza!

Honestly, I don't get the hype. They've got Michelin stars? Maybe that chef cooks dinner, because lunch was decidedly "meh". The menu had your typical Thai restaurant dishes, which may or may not bear resemblance to what they actually eat in Thailand.  Ordered a yellow curry, which was fine flavor-wise, though hardly warranted the little chili pepper next to the dish warning me that it would be hot. It was not remotely hot.  The chicken had obviously been boiled earlier and thrown in at the end, which I hate. I get it saves time, but it's rubbery and bland because it didn't cook with the rest of the dish. I don't know who they think they foolin' with that cop out move.  Service was extremely inattentive, and the place was practically empty, so I'm not sure why.  The heat was either malfunctioning or turned very low. I realize that's my particular nit but I'll pick it.  All in all, I'd rather go the extra few blocks south to Sticky Rice.

I think I've finally found my go-to Thai place in Chicago! Very authentic Thai food, very tasty and in a good comfortable setting! Pros: - The food! Everything was 5-Star quality! Yummy yummy yummy in our tummies! - friendly wait staff - parking wasn't hard to find at all (although we were there on a Wednesday evening... Dunno how weekends would be) - what a good menu! Finally far more dishes than the typical Pad Thai, Tom Yum, and thai curries! Lots of noodles, rice, and soup choices, lots of appetizer choices and desserts too - great for vegetarians! The wait staff told us that they could make almost anything vegetarian! - oh did I mention that every dish was yummy-licious?  Cons: - no cons really ... Just that this isn't a fine dining restaurant and I hope you don't walk in expecting that. We didn't.  - The fact that we had to pay a buck for white rice ... Thai dishes need the rice, would be better to just build the price into the dish's price Check out our photos...  Oh, did I say that every dish we tried was yummmmmmmy!?

Decidedly mediocre. But I keep hitting reorder on the Yelp app (because I am lazy) about every 10 days. And how do they thank their repeat customers? Decreasing portion sizes substantially.  Tonight I opened my bag to find that the size of my regular three side orders of peanut sauce were a third of the size they used to be -- and only half full! So, you get about a tablespoon of peanut sauce -- with the same $1.00 price tag.  Has to be a mistake, right? New person working in the kitchen? Nope!  I called and the person on the phone said that management had changed the "protocol" for the size of the side order to make it smaller. Cool.  I'm not a scientist - but I would have to imagine there is a study or two out there that demonstrates a high correlation between decreased patronage and customers feeling they have been taken advantage of.  But no biggie for me. According to Yelp, there are like five different Thai places within a stone's throw from me.  Hi Opart Thai competition! Looking forward to sending my $30 order to you every 10 days.

I really like this place.  Every time I go the ingredients seem so fresh.  I love the papaya and beef salad.  Anything spicy here is just perfect too.   Service is what can be expected, it's fast and efficient but I'm not coming here to be bff with the waitstaff. Lard Nar with tofu is fantastic. The crispy spring rolls are another go to of mine.   Crab rangoon is another must have but only in house, not for delivery.   While I love their neighbor, Rainbow, up the street just a little bit more, this place is still always on my hit list.

I told the tall waitress with the male voice that I wanted a side of tofu.  She decided to go ahead and order me the fried tofu appetizer,  which was not my intention. Rice is not included in any of the dishes.   You must pay for it.
I love this place!! Pad thia is legit ....amazing service and so fast! Great price and byob! Very kid friendly...peanut lovers dish is so good, pork dumpling, peanut chicken, spicy shrimp yum!

I am shocked that this location has a 4 star rating. We usually eat at the south loop location and the food is great. We tried this location because we were in the neighborhood. Terrible. Witnessed some disgusting habits by staff and the food was bad. Even my kids complained.

I expected more from this restaurant from the reviews but when my friends and I ate here their food was very bland. We asked for medium spice and what we got was no spice. I don't know if it was just an off day for them, but out of the four items we ordered, I did not care for a single one.

We LOVE Opart Thai! We go at least once a month. It's BYOB and they do not have a corking fee. My husband and I usually order 3 appetizers and a soup. Our favorite appetizers are the Tiger Cry, Crab Rangoon and Peanut Spring Rolls. Our favorite soup is the coconut soup.  The staff is nice and the environment is relaxing. Highly recommend!

We've eaten here a few times.  The food is pretty good and it's convenient to our home.  The service is hit or miss, typical of what I've experienced in similar restaurants.  But they have a great menu with lots of options.  We'll keep going back.

This continues to be a repeat favorite.  The beef Kra Pow is awesome (I probably spelled that wrong) and the portions are generous.   I was a little disappoint by the crab rangoon as they were mostly dough and lacked in filling.  That's not enough to stop me from coming back, though!

My favorite Thai place in the north side. I LOVE everything they have here. The tiger cry is a must try if you haven't already. I also always get the papaya salad and pad Kee Mao here. So sad I don't live in the north side anymore but I'd go there any chance I could.

A family favorite. I really like their appetizers the most - I usually order one or two for my meal. I need to explore the curries more as I have only sampled other's dishes but they are always super tasty!  *Fried Potstickers - one of my favorite foods. Delicious soy sauce. Yummy pork. All around, so good!  *Crab Rangoon - guilty pleasure of mine.  *Tiger Cry - a friend introduced me to this one. Charred perfection!  *Pad See-lew w/ Chicken - not my favorite in the city but totally good.  *Thai Iced Tea - a must order! Everyone in my family loves this.

Crappy online app- ordered 3 curry dishes that normally come with rice- got delivery and no rice.  Called and told if you order online you have to order  rice separately.  I asked where since there was not spot on app to order only rice- was told in extras. There is no extras. Attitude and money creep (app costs more). Wish they would just answer the phone and I would t need their app.

Me, my brother, sister and cousin wanted to try a different Thai restaurant for a change and this place came highly recommended by my coworker... Free parking can be difficult to find. We were lucky to park on one of the side streets. They have spacious seating options with a old wood floor and seats. We absolutely enjoyed the Sampler plate, Tiger cry, Beef pad thai, Pork pad thai, Chicken panang curry medium spice level, Chicken pad see-iew, and Combination fried rice. Price for portion was reasonable.Service was OK since they apparently repeated all our orders correctly but forgot one of the orders.
Service was friendly and good. Appetizers were decent. Entrees tasted like they were previously frozen lacked some flavor. The ambiance is solid at this place I wish food was a little better.
Hands down the best Thai food in Chicago. Gang Panang Curry with shrimp is delicious. The Tiger's Cry is awesome as well.

Not sure what all the hype is. Just your normal nothing special Thai place in Chicago. This tastes like every other Thai place you might order delivery from when you're trying to find your next go-to Thai restaurant. The quest continues...
Chose the BBQ & rice. It was some over cooked beef with not much flavor and some unsavory sauce over a whole lot of sticky rice.

If I could give no stars, I would. We walked in and there was a damp odor in the air. We should have left, but we were swayed by the reviews. We ordered pad and chicken fried rice--the most basic of basic dishes--both orders were disappointing. The pad thai was waayy too sweet and the fried rice wasn't fried. To make it worse, my seat was wet when we sat down and there was a puddle on the ground at my feet. The waitress asked me if I wanted her to mop it up... :| The whole time we're we're wishing we tried Rosded instead. If you haven't been here, don't go. If this is your regular spot, I question your taste buds. Also, I would just like to add that I literally have only reviewed places I have liked. My experience at this place has changed that decision.

I had heard this Thai place was not what it was, but I was tired so I gave it a try. I had been here years ago for pad thai which was nothing special. I ordered a red curry with roasted duck, and asked for it med-hot. What I rec'd was mild and just warm in temperature. The dish itself had possibilites if heat had been there. Will not try again. I know there are a lot of glowing reviews, but not my experience.

We have loved Opart since moving to Lincoln Square in 2008.  Our standard order is Panang Curry, Green Curry, Crab Rangoon, Spicy Fried Tofu, occasionally Pad Thai for old school kicks.  We have always loved it but quality had been falling off recently, so we tried a few other neighborhood Thai places, and none were as delicious, so we're back with Opart for our delivery dinner dates.  The medium spicy is just right for husband, and I prefer mild - all the dishes are tasty but too spicy can sometimes upset my belly.  We have dined in also but I think you get bigger portions when ordering delivery/take out, and delivery can be slow so plan to order at least an hour or more in advance of when you want to actually eat on a weekend around dinner time.  If delivery were faster and the consistency was 100% (instead of 90%) I'd give another star in a flash!

I very much enjoyed Opart Thai and would gladly eat here again. There were some items I liked more than others, but everything was tasty. The Tiger Cry stood out as far as appetizers and the Fried Banana (banana in an egg roll wrapper) was the dessert winner. We passed our entrées around family style, so I had the opportunity to try a lot of different dishes and get a good idea of what I'd want to order again when I return. I was set on ordering the Tiger Cry after I saw it referenced in a few Yelp reviews and found it to be even better than I was expecting. I could have easily ordered 2 portions and made this its own meal. We couldn't decide what else to get, so we went with the Sampler Platter and it was OK. My favorite part was the Crab Rangoon, so I'd get that again. The Fried Shumai were alright, but I could skip them next time. The Egg Roll and the Fried Shrimp Spring Roll didn't do much for me but were enjoyed by others. We got Fresh Spring Rolls, too. The sauces that accompanied the appetizers were kind of what really had people talking since they were very good and went well on just about anything you put them on. We all ordered something completely different or slight variations of entrées. One person got the Peanut Sauce Lover, which was one of my favorites, especially the sauce. She ordered it medium-hot, which I was able to handle, though it did open up my sinuses and had me tearing up a little bit. For others, this was a bit too hot. Everyone else mostly got mild or medium spiciness. I ordered Gaeng Panang with pork and medium. Another friend got Gaeng Panang with beef and mild. I'm pretty sure another was Pad See-Iew with chicken, which was very good. Another favorite was another Yellow Curry with coconut milk, Gaeng Musaman. And there was a finely chopped beef meal called Pad Ka-Prao that had ginger and was very spicy to me even though it was ordered medium. Be warned the the Thai Custard is not the way most would think of a custard. It's much more like a hot, mushy cake. I really liked it but my companions were turned off by it since they had something else in mind. They were not at all stingy with the rice and even provided extra in the take-out containers when we left.

Opart is our go to Thai place! My boyfriend and I absolutely love spicy food, and opart does not fail to satisfy our fire! Take that as a warning for those of you who aren't used to high level of spice. Even the "medium" level can be too spicy for some of my friends who claim they like spicy food. I prefer asking for spicy everything, and let me tell you I am sweating while eating here. Their Tom Yum is the best hot and sour soup I have ever had. I've had it with both chick and shrimp but prefer the shrimp. I'm also a sucker for coconut curry, but don't like white rice. There's a dish called Khao Soy... coconut curry soup on top of egg noodle topped with lime cilantro and crispy egg noodle. Oh my gosh, so satisfying. Love this place!

I went for a business lunch. Decent and quick service. Good flavors, but the medium spice level was pretty spicy for me. Next time I go, I would definitely ask for less than medium, but not mild. Had Thai milk tea after lunch. It was very good and refreshing.

One of the best thai restaurants I've been to in Chicago -- unassuming, located near the brown line on Western Ave, it didn't look like much from the outside. But once you find yourself inside, you'll realize the restaurant is actually quite large, with ample seating and archways that lead you to more seats inside restaurant.  Service was great, my fiance and I tried their thai tea and it was definitely legit. For appetizers, we had their crab rangoon which was just amazing, fresh, perfectly crispy and very well portioned. For the main course we had the panang curry and pad see ew -- the curry was hands down my favorite, with the perfect amount of flavor and heat, moist chicken a bed of rice.  Probably my only gripe was that they charged $1 extra for rice, and they are a bit pricier than the other restaurants I've been to... but I'm sure they know they've got a great thing going.  Parking: Street parking, metered except for Sundays (free!)  BYOB  Great for dates, great for family  Must try: the crab rangoon :P  Dine in or delivery, we'll definitely be back!

Stumbled upon this place on Yelp while searching for dinner in the area and I am so glad we found it!  Large dining room = no wait on a Friday night. The two dishes I had were fantastic. Peanut sauce spring rolls were super fresh and smothered in what is perhaps the best peanut sauce I've ever had. I also tried the Khao Soy (coconut curry noodles), which they happily made vegetarian for me, which was one of the best dishes I've ever had in a Thai restaurant in the U.S. I tried this same dish in Thailand, and this one was nearly identical and perfectly spiced. Portions were generous, and everything our group ordered seemed very fresh, and very reasonably priced.

would've given 4 stars as it's Always been really good and satisfying when i've dined in.  however, ordering out has more than once been disappointing.  it's not just the portions, it's the subpar taste.  what i used to consider great has slid down to just-ok.   that said, i'd definitely go back to dine in
Bugs! (Yelp is requiring I post more than just one word so here are extra words.)

I've been a steady customer for over 15 years. Their Tom Yum soup is tangy and spicy. And no tomatoes! I don't get to motors in soup.   I am also a big fan of Oparts beef salad.  Nice char grilled pieces of (I think) skirt steak?  The lime dressing is the best.   They have surprising good won ton soup.  The spring rolls are fresh. A year or so back the quality seemed to be slipping but they're back to the Opart I love.

Great Thai place with BYOB and a liquor store next to it! Steps from the Western brown line stop. We took the train here on a Friday night, popped into the liquor store next door for a 6 pack and then had some wonderful thai food. Not the most glamorous restaurant but just incredible food and a cozy atmosphere! Food: Curry fried rice Beer: BYOB!

I have read good reviews for this place so I thought that this may be a good place to have some decent Saturday dinner.  Now I don't make a lot of bad reviews. However the food itself is just mediocre enough to warrant this review. The noodles are overcooked (we ordered khee mao, pad thai, and pad see iew.) All of what we ordered are pretty standard fare for a Thai restaurant not mess up. They are also lacking the quintessential Thai taste: meaning that they were bland, flavor profiles not balanced and everything seems to have been cooked in a less hot wok and hurried, no quality control. For 40 bucks worth of food, I have hoped for better.

Friendly, helpful staff!  We had the pad thai with tofu, and pad prik king with tofu.  While I have other favorite places for these, Opart was still great!  The pad thai was standard, basic slightly peanutty, somewhat tamarind-y, with noodles cooked right.  The prik king had great spices, firm green beans, the right amount of sauce.  I'd go back.

I very rarely give 5 stars, but Opart is definitely deserving. Our airbnb hosts suggested this for a healthy dinner for us while we are in town for Lollapalooza. The tricky part of travelling for us is our diverse menu choices. My daughter and her bff are strictly vegan. I'm a casual vegetarian known to do chicken if there is a Popeyes nearby. My wife is none of the above, still a carnivore. Finding restaurants to fit our needs wouldn't be possible without Yelp, so here is my official thanks to Yelp shout out.  We arrived at Opart after a full day of sightseeing in Chi town. I have to admit that we were dragging, and e of the 4 if us were cranky. I'm always a happy boy. The menu looked great, more importantly the seats were comfortable and the ac was pumping cool deliciousness into the air.  We started with 2 orders of spring rolls, and our server had no problem with our request to leave the eggs out. The rolls were served with some sliced jalapenos, which I thought was a nice touch. They were delish and very filling. I ordered the curry fried rice with tofu. I wish I could have ordered it with chicken, but my daughter was watching. Back story. I used to live in Miami FL before moving to Charlotte 8 years ago. I used to frequent a Thai joint that served curry fried rice. I never found a rice dish anywhere in my travels that equaled what Sea Siam in Miami served. Until I went to Opart. One word? Fantasticallydelish! It was fried to perfection, and I was blown away by the flavor. If I could have ordered to go as well I would have. My girls were very happy with their meals too, our waiter was fantastic. I can't wait to go back, which is the highest praise I can offer to a restaurant.

The Thai ice coffee?? I love the food , but the last three visits the Thai ice coffee was awful. Twice watered down and the last time a cup full of grounds on the bottom, what's going on? Never had this problem at any Thai restaurant . Please fix the problem!
Ordered food and was told restaurant couldn't be reached after 45 minutes. Left with hungry kids and no food. I will not be eating at Opart or ordering via Eat24 in the future.

I can't believe I haven't written a review for Opart Thai yet. I think I first stopped in over 7 years ago, at the recommendation of a friend who lives nearby. I had the pad see ewe that time, and just about every other time after that. I don't know what it is about pad see ewe from Opart Thai, but it's my favorite thai food. Once in a while I switch things up and order pad thai, which is also very good, but it's typically pad see ewe. The spring rolls are tasty too. I usually get an order to share with my husband. One con is that delivery can take a bit of time, so I more often than not order for pick up.

Order the eggrolls.  I don't care if you don't like eggrolls.  Just get them.  Best I've had in my life.  Excellent food, but if you ask for it spicy...be prepared.  It's f'ing hot as hell.  But yanno, good.  But hot.  P.S. Get eggrolls.

Omg do not come here!!!!!!!! It's horrible and food has no flavor at all! This place has legit disappointed me. At first I seen a lot of people and thought to myself well it must be good. Even with the warning of people coming out to to run. Everyone has different taste but man I should've ran away.
Arrived on a Saturday evening and had to wait a second to get a seat. Menu is a little dated, but has a lot of great option on it. All in all was some good food.

This place serves very Americanized thai food. The flavors are watered down. We got three different dishes (pad Thai, pad sewee and a curry). They all fell flat. Not worthy of a repeat visit for someone who really enjoys good Thai food. But if you like familiar American flavors or subtle flavors go for it. I won't detour from Siam noodle on Leland/Sheridan again.
Neighborhood street parking. Restaurant environment is nice. Customer service good. Food was yummy. Ordered take out and food was ready in 20 minutes. Will be back!

We've been here several times and they are very consistent.  Food is great.  Appetizer sampler is s good mix.  They ran out of potstickers on a Saturday afternoon which is our favorite item on the menu.  Eggplant dish is very good!  Tom Yum soup is fantastic!  Don't order the pepper steak; it's not terrible, it's just bland and flavorless. Service is very good.  The servers pay attention to their area and check on you frequently.  Lots of people were walking in to pick up their take out orders which is a great sign!   We will definitely keep coming back.
I can say but one thing. Best yellow curry EVER!!!! I enjoy it with tofu and sweet potato!
The appetizer sample plate was good..  The dishes were not so great and lacked the flavor Pho thai & Siam in edgewater are much better..  Nice ambiance but the taste could be lot better

Exceptional place...very authentic!! Best Pad Thai BY FAR of any Thai place I've been too...and I've been to MANY Thai places!! But watch out if you order something spicy because they are SERIOUSLY spicy!

Fresh Spring Rolls - tasted like nothing. The sauce didn't help either. Bami Pad Pak - did not taste good. I also asked for pork and received chicken. Seafood Combination - the squid was too tough but it was a decent dish Cucumber Delight and Brown Rice - ok, you can't really mess these up... So I was kind of disappointed but I think I may give them a second chance - I want to try the Tiger Cry the other reviewers have mentioned. So stay tuned!

I will say the food was good, servers were friendly...but had terrible stomach issues the next 2 days, probably from all the coconut milk used in Thai cooking? I would say if  you can handle Thai, go for it! The fried tofu was really yummy with the sauce it came with; I'm a tofu nut. The yellow curry I had was really good, wish it came with more rice. I should have asked for but I was on a terrible date and just wanted to run. I highly recommend that if you go during the colder months to get seated on the other side, people can be rude about not letting the first door close before the open the next one so it gets DRAFTY but Opart keeps the place well heated so you'll warm up fast. I would say for Thai in the city pretty good but not the BEST.  I will apologize though for my date. He was offensively LOUD and RUDE when ANNOUNCING to tell me upon my arrival that he thought the servers behind him at the counter were gay because one looked like a manly woman. Seriously, that's just plain rude of him and I'm so sorry! :( ...needless to say I wont be seeing that one again lol BUT YEA....eat it at your own risk if you cant do a LOT of coconut milk. I'm surprised by my reaction to it since normally I am fine. Most of the meat can be switched to tofu. Yellow curry and fried tofu yummy!

I was at the Western Ave location last night with a friend.  Midway through the meal, a large cockroach crawled across the table about 5 inches away from my plate. I eat out pretty regularly, and have been to some dumpy dives in my time, but I've never seen a cockroach on the table next to my food. If there are roaches in the dining room, i can only imagine what the kitchen must be like. Needless to say, I'll NEVER eat there again.

Solid Thai food (with all the greatest hits on the menu).   BYOB (there is a liquor store right next store).  Service has never blown me away, but have never had an unacceptable experience.   Probably not worth going out of your way for, but definitely worth a try if in the neighborhood.
Good little BYO Thai joint. Service is quick. The menu is huge. Come with an appetite. Check my pics for review of the food

This is one of my favorite Thai places in Chicago.  I have been here many times and never been disappointed.  They are NOT shy with the spice either.  If you ask for a spicy curry, be prepared for your eyes and nose to gush, so adjust accordingly!  My #1 favorite thing to order is the Tiger Cry, and I am not much of a fan of beef either.  They are perfectly juicy and tender.  Customer service is very quick is as well!

This place was okay, nothing grand. Went here on Friday night, was seated right away. Employees don't look happy, they're there for the paycheck, which is fine. Had a curry dish with shrimp. It was tasty, will go back for that. My friend had pad thai and said it was okay. Also had the banana egg rolls. Did not like it, hot on the outside but cold in the inside. The decor was standard and nice.

The food is tasty, but... Watch out.  The staff felt like going home, so they closed an. hour early.  They argued that they  really close at 10, even though the sign and Yelp says 11.  And they wouldn't even do take out. "The kitchen won't want to."  So, though I've come here a dozen times, I might be done.  Good luck.

We ordered shrimp toast and egg rolls, which were very good. However, we ordered wonton soup which was inedible, soggy, and flavorless. We also ordered fried rice medium spicy. The rice was colorless and flavorless. It was not spicy in any way. Overall we were really disappointed. We live down the street and the delivery took over an hour and did not send any soy sauce, napkins, etc. very disappointing.
Love this place, it is my "go to" for great Thai food. One of the best in the city. Worth a trip if you are not in the immediate vicinity. BYOB just enhances the whole experience.

Opart is our go-to Thai restaurant in the neighborhood because my wife likes it more than the others (Rainbow, Roseded, Spoon, Sticky Rice), but I'm always a little disappointed by what I get.  The spiciness level is often inconsistent (spicy is either way too tolerable, or totally inedible), so its hard to gauge how to order.  Some dishes are really good, specifically the Kao Soy, but many are sort of lack luster and i find the menu a bit limited compared to Roseded, Spoon, and Sticky Rice.

Opart Thai has never disappointed me.  I've ordered the Pad Paak Roum Mit, Pad King, and Pepper Steak.  All of them were delicious.  Also, the Thai iced tea was great!  As far as city pricing goes, Opart Thai is very reasonable (part of that is because it's BYOB).  The staff here is friendly, and really just no complaints.

There is better Thai food all over Chicagoland. The decor and service was great, but all the food was over-sauced and bland. When my peppered steak comes out swimming in a pool of gravy, you know it's Americanized asian cuisine. Check out Royal Thai, only a few blocks away on Montrose.
Two stars because the service was okay and the decor is nice. I've had a lot of Thai food and this was bland and didn't seem as fresh as other places like Medee Cafe and Indie Cafe.
The food and customer servive were great.  The fried banana was a little too sweet but it tasted good. The noodle dishes has chinese broccoli.
Solid delicious meal. Can always count on my meal being fresh and delicious. Service has always been great!

Opart Thai on Western near Lawrence is one of the mainstay Thai restaurants of Lincoln Square that I have visited a few times over the years.  The food here is good if not great, but with an extensive menu you should find something to dine on.  The interior is pleasantly decorated, though if you sit in the first dining area you may feel an occasional gust of wind from the outside.  There are so many selections on the menu and the names are so Thai that you might just need those numbers preceding each item to order your meal.  On a recent visit I asked our server which she would choose between two dishes.  She immediately said I should go with the khao nar ped, and it turned out to be a good choice.  The pieces of roast duck were flavorful, and the Chinese broccoli and rice made for a simple yet fine meal.  My friend ordered the tom yum koong with a medium level of spiciness.  This is a large vat of Thai hot and sour soup with shrimp, mushrooms, lemon grass and lime juice.  I took one trial sip and although it was flavorful, it was too spicy for me.  My friend gleefully enjoyed the soup, though in the end she could not finish it all because of the generous overall serving size.  The tab was very reasonable, perhaps mainly because we did not order anything else.  The BYOB policy also helps to keep the costs down when you dine at Opart Thai.

Hmm, not sure how this place has such high reviews. It is cute inside, and conveniently located. When I went, there were six of us and probably ten minutes passed between the first entree coming out and the last. So that was a little awkward.  As for the food: Nothing was all that great. Crab rangoon was way too sweet, as was the peanut sauce. Shrimp appetizer was okay. I had the Khee Mao, medium spicy. Spice level was high, but tolerable. The chicken tasted weird but the veggies were fresh. My husband had the same dish with pork; I found the pork piece I sampled to be very chewy and also somewhat off.

Opart is my absolute favorite Thai in the city.  And lucky me, I just so happen to live 5 minutes away from it.  I am absolutely never disappointed with the food.  Some of my favorite entrees are Khao Soy, Gaeng Keow Waan (green curry), Gaeng Gari (yellow curry- ok basically you can't go wrong with the curry), Woon Sen Pad Thai, Tom Yum Koong (Shrimp-huge pieces of shrimp and straw mushrooms).  My favorite apps are the TIGER CRY (an absolute must!), tender juicy marinated beef pieces in their homemade vinegar-based sauce, excellent pot stickers, and chicken satay. I generally do take-out which is where you can get a little frustrated with this place.  They are so damn good that they are often overloaded with take-out orders.  They absolutely do their best to process orders quickly but this place is amazing and many people know it so on Sunday or Thursday night be prepared to wait at least an hour for take out.  Sometimes the line can be busy and it can take a few tries to get through on a busy night but don't give up you will get through!  I still think it's worth it.   I've also eaten in the restaurant which is a lovely experience- if you have time I recommend!  It is large inside with much seating and a nice peaceful, Thai vibe.  Last I was there they were BYOB and probably still are.

If you like Thai, go here!  It's the best Chicago has to offer, and that's saying a lot.  I discovered this place about 20 years ago when I lived in the neighborhood, and even though I've moved elsewhere, I still keep going back.  The menu is extensive.  It's not much on decor, but the best restaurants usually aren't.

I think tonight I've given up bothering with Opart Thai. It's not really much of a loss for me, since it's not my favorite cuisine, but it was alright occasionally. I tried calling a few times tonight. I got a busy signal a couple of times, which was no problem; it's a Sunday, the Cubs are in the NLCS so everyone's watching the game, I get it. I just called back. However, when I finally had someone answer the phone, I was put on hold immediately for approximately 10 minutes. I was then taken off hold, as I heard activity in the background and people speaking to one another, and I called out "Hello!" on the phone for about 2 minutes hoping someone would hear me. I know that these times are correct since the phone says how long the calls are and it was 12 minutes total. Clearly no one was hearing me, so I hung up. When I called back, I got a busy signal again so I waited a few minutes to call back. I finally got through after my third call or so. The woman who answered simply said "hold please" and put me immediately on hold. Not only is this one of my biggest pet peeves (being put on hold without being able to say a word), but given that I had just spent 12 minutes on hold I wasn't about to wait again. Their food certainly is not that good. This happens far too often when I call Opart Thai--there's been some variant of this experience the last two or three times I've tried to order, which is why I have vetoed it when my partner has suggested it. So I'm simply not going to bother any longer. They have plenty of devout customers so losing one isn't going to matter to them and others who are willing to be put on hold/forgotten about/etc. will have one fewer customer to compete with.

In addition to dining in, you can now order delivery with the Yelp app. When your food arrives, you just answer the door & get your food; no credit card slips to sign (you can include a tip using the app too, which is great). Opart has been out go to Thai restaurant for YEARS; the high quality of the food has remained consistent throughout.

So my girlfriend and I had ordered takeout, and are both big fans of Thai food. I ordered the Gaeng Pet Ped curry dish, my girlfriend the Poh Tak soup and split a Shu Mai appetizer. Her soup is delicious, as the curry. unfortunately, the curry dish (which was a roast duck curry) was very sparce. To call this a dish, is sad. Great flavor, terrible portion size. 3 pieces of pineapple, 1 peice of a tomato, and a few ounces of duck. It was very underwhelming. If it's because duck is pricey, then up the price and give me a full curry dish. Don't undercut me on the dish for the sake of keeping the price relative to the other curry dishes. Extremely dissapointed.

Okay service and ok food. I've never been to a Thai restaurant that didn't give you na'an. And although the menu says you can order jasmine rice with your curry they gave me long grain rice. Big difference! I wouldn't recommend it.

My most recent visit here, I went with my sister after a long day of shopping. I already love the food here, but this time, the service was awesome. I didn't finish my drink so I asked if I could bring it to go. Being true to my clumsy nature, while trying to pour it into the plastic cup provided to me, I managed to spill it all over the table. While trying to wrestle the ice cubes back into the cup, our waitress made her way towards our table and told us not to worry and that she would take care of it. There was no agitation that could be sensed in her voice. She also provided me with a new drink. Loved the service. Always came back for the food, now I will come back for the service too.

This place is solid.  Very solid.  And very good.  Went here last night on a whim, we were in the area doing some errands, and we decided to stop in here on the way to the brown line.  We first stopped at the basically-adjacent liquor store, ten walked in to Opart and were promptly seated.  The server was very pleasant.  We ordered the Woon Sen Pad Thai with chicken and Pork Fried Rice.  Both were tasty, and the portions were more than satisfying, especially the fried rice.  I am going to try the other Thai places in this area, but Opart has put itself solidly on the "go back" list.

I hadn't been here in years when we stopped back in on Saturday night for dinner. It was exactly as I remembered it, but I have made some personal changes since then, even if the restaurant ostensibly has not. I now follow a vegan diet as much as possible, and I am also a more adventurous eater in terms of flavor profiles, levels of spiciness and ordering things blindly. I used to come here and get the chicken pad thai and crab rangoon, every. single. time. - they were wonderful! But now, in my 'old age', I prefer to always try to order something new when I go out. I asked our server for a recommendation given the above two requirements (veg and new to me), and she said no problem, she could do any dish vegetarian (reassuring, since I was guessing that a lot of sauces might be fish-based). She suggested Pad Ped Paak, which was kind of non-descriptly listed as "Sauteed mixed vegetables and hot peppers with choice of [protein]."  Delicious! The sauce was more of like a salty broth, but it was so savory that I could have eaten down an entire bowl of the stuff. The veggies were so colorful and perfectly cooked, not soggy: broccoli, cauliflower, peapods, cabbage, bell peppers, chili peppers, tomatoes (...?), baby corn and onion (I think). Perfect recommendation for me. My dining partner got the Hot & Spicy Seafood Combo and also loved his food. He ordered it very spicy and got through most of it, but he said it made his scalp start to sweat! I would totally come back here and play Russian roulette again when ordering with whichever served we got, asking for another suggestion.

I absolutely love this place! My favorite things on the menu are shrimp toast, tiger cry, and drunken noodle.   I am editing my review as i went again and did not like the Green Curry that much and as i was getting ready to leave there was a small cockroach walking around. Makes me wonder what's happening in the kitchen.

I was very impressed with this place! We had the Pad Thai and the Kuay Tiew Kee Mao and both were amazing. The noodles in the pad thai were very thin, almost like angel hair pasta noodels. I asked the waitress and she said their noodles are made fresh here daily, they don't soak dry noodles which was pretty cool to know. The beef in my opinion was better than the chicken, this place can also get really spicy, I eat very spicy food and when I told her spicy my food had a really nice kick, had me sweating a bit. The workers here are very helpful and they give very good recommendations. I read on here that the portions are big, they're very average size portions. This place will definitely be my new Thai spot I can't wait to try more things here.

really great thai food that won't cost an arm and a leg! i always get the red curry with chicken. if you like to cry while you eat your food, get the hot version! i try to stick with the medium. it seems spicy enough for me (i love hot food!). the place is really casual and the environment is chill. def one of my favorite thai places on western. will be coming back very soon!
One of the best Thai places in the city.  BYOB to boot!  Anytime I am in the area I'll stop in and order the Tiger Cry.  This is seriously one of the best appetizers I've ever had.

I've eaten here a few times now and I can now conclude that this is THE BEST Thai restaurant in town. I don't even try looking for other Thai places anymore. Everything I've had here has always been so amazing. My current favorites are the tom kha Kai soup, ground chicken with basil and the red curry. I love spicy food and the medium spice level is great for me. If you are looking for an authentic Thai experience, this is the place to go!

New to neighborhood & ordered delivery based on great Yelp reviews and recommendation from a neighbor. Major disappointment. After placing our order by phone and giving credit card the staff person said quickly: "ok, it will be 1 hour" and immediately hung up. We live a few blocks away- 1 hour??? Then, after our food finally arrived, we opened it to discover that no rice was included with the spicy curry dinner. How cheap is that??? To top it off, the food was nothing special. Sadly, this will not be our go-to spot for Thai in the neighborhood.
Good was really good, but the service could have been a little better.  Keep in mind, if you ask for extra spicy, they'll accommodate the request and your food will be spicy.  Yum!

Pretty decent Thai. Fresh seafood. The rangoons are to die for and they stay true to the spicy flavor of Thai food. It didn't knock my socks off but it's a good place of you're itching for some Thai food. Decent portion size as well.

Rather disappointed. We ordered delivery. The crab rangoon was overcooked and chewy. The pad thai was like eating plain rice noodles, the sauce was completely non-existent. The rama chicken sauce was watered down, and didn't come with rice. Won't be ordering from here again.

It's a good place to have Thai food. I am not a Thai expert, but I have had a lot of Thai food in my life. Some Thai food restaurants cook their foods to oily and salty.  Here, the food is well cooked. Also the one thing that will make me come visiting again is the price.

Me and my husband were here last night.. We were fasting the whole day so we were excited to eat our first meal of the day at Opart.. Bad idea.. While we were waiting for our orders we had an uninvited guest it looks like a baby cockroach crawling in the wall.. We were so disgusted.. I wanted to tell the waiter but he seems really busy either.. So my husband had to kill it.. Disgusting!! If they have cockroach in the dining area.. I can't imagine what they have in the kitchen.. We totally lost our appetite and hardly ate our food.. We just paid and left.. Never ever coming back in this place

I used to be a regular here but I've had two bad experiences in a row, so I won't be back.  About a month ago I called in an order, it included a dish which came with your choice of meat. I requested extra broccoli as a substitute for meat. I was told I would be charged extra for the broccoli. This seemed unfair as broccoli is generally a cheaper product than the meat options on offer.  Last night I called to place an order, I was immediately put on hold, which is fine. I was on hold for seven minutes with no follow up. I hung up and called again, before I had the opportunity to tell them I had been waiting seven minutes to place an order, I was put on hold again.  We decided to give Rosded (across the road from Opart) a try, It felt like they were happy to have our business and the food was good, so they'll definitely get another chance.  The food at Opart has always been pretty good, but I don't think they place any value on your custom, so that leaves a bad taste in the mouth.

This is one of my favorite Thai spots in the city.   It continues to do everything just right.  We had a spring roll appetizer, pad thai and combination seafood fried rice.  Leftovers togo and full bellies all the way around!

Seriously the worst service I've experienced. The transgender waitress talked to me as if I was an idiot with a blank stare. The second waitress didn't seem like she was "there" We were not greeted. No hi, how are you or thank you when we left either. Literally EVERYONE HAD THE MOST DISGUSTING attitude and I could not understand why for the life of me. Not to mention we were given our check before they even knew I was done eating and this was about 30mins before closing. (That's okay, I'm ready to get tf up outta here anyway) The food was really good which I hate to admit because of the horrible service but I don't think I would dine in again just bc of that.

There are not many Thai Restuarant that satisified me because they can't make my dishes spicy enough.  Till this day, Opart is my favorite thai restuarant, it's tasty and spicy. I always order the basil beef and green curry.  Not to mention this place is also BYOB!

Second time going and we had to try the Tiger Cry. It was as good as everyone says. You can taste it being right off the grill. Crab Rangoon is of course a favorite of mine, and really done well here. The soups are amazing with the lemon grass and great presentation in the bowl they serve in. We order appetizers and soup and that is filling enough for me before we even get to our main meal.  I haven't found a main dish that I liked yet, I tried a pineapple curry dish that I did not care for and a Pan King that was a bit too spicy for me even though it was mild.  All in all a great place that we will be going back too, especially for the soup!

My go-to Thai place. I'm so lucky that my favorite Thai restaurant in the city happens to be within walking distance of my house - plus they deliver for when I feel extra lazy. GET THE TIGER CRY. It will give you the meat orgasm you didn't know you were missing. I also love the egg drop soup and the basil fish. The only downside is if you eat in house (which I rarely do) it can be tough to get seated, especially with more than 2 people. Just get delivery and stay in your sweatpants like the awesome sloth you are.

I thought the food here was outstanding and really well priced for the quality and portion size. We ordered the crab Rangoon: fantastic. The frying wasn't overdone and the crab meat and cream cheese mixture was fresh and creamy. We also ordered the tiger fly based on previous reviews and HOT DAMN THAT SHIT WAS GOOD. Delicious beef cooked to perfection with house made sauce. Shared a huge pot of fresh lavender tea for under $2 and I got yellow curry as my main dish--super flavorful with a mild kick. I will be going back. One of my new favorites in Chicago.

I had to order some food for a lunch I was having for an office and they requested Opart Thai House. Since I had to feed several people who didn't have any recommendations as to their favorite dishes I went in blind. The menu has tons of fantastic options and although I know what I like, I was a little overwhelmed on where to even begin making sure I ordered things that everyone would be happy with. One of the servers, Anitra, offered to put together several of their more popular dishes plus her own recommendations to create a well rounded variety saving me the confusion. She did such a wonderful job, everyone loved it! I'm so grateful for her help, good taste and saving me a ton of time. The food was amazing. I will definitely be returning.

Came here with a group of four...I have become a thai food snob ever since I came back from Thailand. So I can be harsh with many places but this place was on point. We shared the tum yum kai, I usually judge a Thai place by their tum yum and they did an excellent job. It is BYOB so bring your wine for the dine. I ordered the masuman curry chicken and it was perfect. Will come again. Service was on par and no wait.
I'm only giving this place 4 stars because the food is great. Don't go there for the service. Its the best thai food in the area that Ive found so far - and Ive been to all the surrounding ones.

Three stars isn't bad.  Its exactly what it is: "Ok." We lived in the area for almost 3 years and never managed to try this place.  Our old neighbor told us it was awesome.  The first time she came she actually ordered the same dish she had for dinner as a to-go because it was so good she wanted more for tomorrow. When this former neighbor stopped by to visit us we decided to stop in and try this place so she could re-live her heaven. Here is what we ordered: Chicken Satay: I'm a vegetarian so I didn't try this.  But the sweet cucumber salad it comes with and the peanut sauce it also comes with were fabulous. Spicy Fried Tofu: All three of us some how missed that it comes with chicken on top (we still swear it wasn't on the menu, but who knows....)  When it came out with chicken, we asked if we could have it re-done.  In hind-sight it didn't matter.  It tasted strange. Sort of like dirty feet. Not one of us liked it.  (Ant the neighbor I mentioned is not a picky eater!)  This pretty much went un-touched. Pad Thai: This was my order. It was Ok. Nothing out of this world. I secretly kept wanting more "sauce" or flavor or something. If there was soy sauce on the table I probably would have dumped some on.  Despite thinking it was only OK, I certainly hoovered down the leftovers for breakfast the next day. Vegetable Fried Rice: This was very bland. I certainly wanted more flavor on this. It was OK.  Nothing bad, just not real exciting. Pad Prik King: this was my husbands selection.  When I tasted it I wasn't crazy about it, but I also had nothing against it. But he said he thought it was really good and he cleaned his plate. Gaeng Panang:  this was the neighbors dish that she ordered two of last time she ate here. I gave her sauce a taste and it was very good. So overall, it was just OK.  They only charged us for the one fried tofu that we actually ate.  Our waitress was very friendly and answered all of our questions graciously.  We could tell they were severely understaffed so things were slow, but everyone was nice. I'm not holding this against them at all.

Great place for Thai or Chinese food. Quick service and it is BYOB. You know they get a lot of business but at the same time you can walk in and get seated right away. They will help to customize a meal if you are able to explain exactly why you'd like.

The best Thai I've had thus far in the city.  Case in point is the fact that the place is packed most weekends and calling in for takeout is what I imagine calling a radio station for free concert tickets is like.  I know it's cliché to say, but everything I've had on the menu has been good and/or excellent.  Make sure you bring a Chardonnay, Champagne, or a shandy or fruit beer to accompany your meal; the place is BYOB.  Starters I've enjoyed are the Satay, Tiger Cry, and Spicy Fried Tofu; the Larb Kai (Chicken Salad) and Neau Nom Tom (grilled beef salad) are standouts too.  For main dishes, I mainly stick to the Hot and Spicy area of the menu and order the items extra spicy from there.  The Peanut Sauce Lovers, Pad Ma Moung Him Ma Pan, Pad Prik, and Pad Ped Paak are my go-tos, usually ordered with tofu.  Honorable mentions go to the Pad Thai, Gaeng Gari, and Gaeng Musaman.

This is the best thai restaurant in Chicago. I hate to be 'that guy,' but I lived in Thailand and this food is not only the most authentic but also the hands down most flavorful and careful thai food out there. My pad Thai was not swimming in sauce. It tasted lightly grilled, with hints of fish sauce and garlic, with the scallions and peanuts punctuating the underlying deliciousness. My girlfriend got the khao soy and it was rich as hell. The place is byob, so bring your best booze. The prices are reasonable as hell.
Visit this Thai restaurant if you're ever in the area. You'll be served with authentic and quality Thai food. You won't regret!

Fantastic Thai place that, so far, hasn't disappointed one bit. Stand-outs include the Tiger Cry, Tom Yum Koong, Penang, Pad Prik King and Pad Sei Ieu. Also some of the best wonton soup I have had in ages -- you can tell the dumplings are truly homemade and, even though this is not a traditional Thai soup, they do a great job and definitely add a Thai flair with their addition of ground chicken. I've heard the Kao Soi is a must order here, and I would like to try that the next time.  Another BIG PLUS in my book is, they know spicy! Nothing is more disappointing to me when you specify "very spicy" for a dish you are ordering, and they wimp out.   Too many Thai (and other ethnic restaurants that specialize in spicy cuisine) tend to tone down their spice levels for an American palate. So, when I specify "very spicy" or let's say a "10" on a scale of 1-10, it tends to fall way short of what I really want. Not the case at Opart. When I ask for it a 10 -- it probably comes out a 15! So, if you like spicy the way I do, be sure to specify (particularly with the Penang/curries and Tom Yum -- it is out of this world good) and if you are not a spice-lover, fear not, there has always been an abundence of great choices on the menu for those in our party who prefer dishes on the mild side.  Note on my star ratings: only reason I am not giving Opart five stars, is that five stars, for me, are really reserved for best in class and the absolute *best* Thai restaurant in America, that I've experienced so far, is Lotus of Siam in Las Vegas. This is not a slight on Opart, which as of now is definitely my favorite in the Chicagoland area.

This review is for the pad thai... I picked up carry-out after reading the amazing yelp reviews and was impressed by the packed restaurant - not so many thai places can jam them in like this. So you can imagine my surprise when I got home and found it to be relatively flavorless. It wasn't terrible, just ok. I know pad thai is about as unexciting as a thai dish as you can get, but I can't help it - I love it. The crab rangoon and cucumber salad were great. I'll try again since it's convenient to my commute home and try a different dish. If you live in the neighborhood, I'd suggest giving it a whirl - just don't go for pad thai. Not sure this place would be worth a long drive from another neighborhood.

This place rocks. Every time my wife and i want to get Thai we come to this place. A short walk, we stop at the liquor store next door to grab a bottle of wine as this place is BYOB. I've tried multiple curries, a couple pad Thai dishes and the peanut spring rolls. All are very satisfying. I can't claim it's the best Thai food ever, but it's pretty damn good. The ambiance is cozy and warm, and usually always fairly full during dinner time. Great for a date night eating Thai over a bottle of wine. Haven't been disappointed yet.

My buddy took me here for the first time and I fell in love with their Tiger Cry. My buddy says they have the best tiger cry, and I can second that. I even dreamt about Opart's tiger cry. The place seemed to get busy, but when we went there for dinner, we had a great time. Great environment, great food, and the customer service was good. I would definitely recommend this place to everyone, and even take my other friends here.

my run of mediocre Thai food in Chicago continues with Opart Thai House.  I've had dinner here at least a half dozen times, and aside from the first time (which was excellent), it has been pretty pedestrian since. pros:  The peanut sauce spring rolls are pretty good, and the dipping sauce is very good.   The service is quick and friendly. They have take out and delivery. Cons: The pot stickers are like you're eating a pork-filled cake. And the pork is sometimes undercooked. The peanut sauce lover entree is not for lovers of the peanut sauce, because they ration that stuff like it's gold. Satay is mediocre at best. Overall, this is one of the better Thai places around, but the bar is set very low here in Chicago.  The food at Opart has been excellent, but they are inconsistent...  And mediocre has pretty much been the rule rather than the exception.

Best. I scheduled to meet up here with two of my friends, one of which explained that she used to come here ~20 years ago as a kid with her family.  I mean if this place has been around this long, they must be doing something right. We sat at a table, put in our orders for some spring rolls and a meat appetizer (I believe tiger cry).  Now here is when i was blown away.  We were given our appetizer within 1 minute.  Probably the fastest turnaround on an appetizer in my life.  And holy crap, the peanut sauce on the spring rolls was delicious. Here's where it got interesting, the Tiger Cry was placed on my table.  This is when I knew that I would be coming back here again.  I'm going to write the word delicious 10 times in an effort to capture my satisfaction with this dish. DELICIOUS DELICIOUS DELICIOUS DELICIOUS DELICIOUS DELICIOUS DELICIOUS DELICIOUS DELICIOUS DELICIOUS Ok yes, back to the food. We shared three entrees, I dont even remember what they were because I was in a blissful state while consuming them. You HAVE to try this Thai place.  Probably my favorite in the city.

Went for the first time last night. I'd give 3.5 if I could, but bottom line is I'd be back and try more another time. I checked on here to take advice from other posts, and everyone said Tiger Cry. So I went for it.... Awesome!!! Superbly marinated beef, and a great hot dipping sauce. Great flavor with or without the sauce, and little bite sized pieces. I got it with white rice and it was a nice and not overwhelmingly heavy dinner. My friend got a peanut chicken dinner and white rice and he got a ton of food for the overall price.  My only issue was a bit of a sour odor as soon as we entered the front room. I didn't notice it in the inner room where we were sitting. After we started, I didn't even notice anymore. Fast service and lots of people too, easy street parking..... I'll try it again.

So, I grew up in Seattle, where Thai and Vietnamese food are about as common as fried chicken joints in Chicago--every major intersection and strip mall.  Moving to the Midwest has been a painful transition with a dearth of even passable Thai to be found in Indiana; when the hubby and I made it to Chicago, I finally had my Thai cravings mostly satisfied by Opart.  Now, it's not as good as the Thai food in Thailand (which is amazing), but it is decidedly the best I've found in Chicago and indeed in the Midwest.  The fact that it's also very reasonably priced is a big help, too, in a city where $15 for a greasy Chinese takeout dish is not considered abnormal.  Here's the thing with Opart: you have to know how to modify the items you like to your preferences. For example:  --some have complained that the curries lack veggies.  I have tried every one on the menu, and I agree if you get them as printed on the menu they seem short of veggies.  The reason? In Thailand they usually do not add many veggies to curry.  BUT: you must know that for $2 extra you can add "extra veggies" to any of them.  They will also let you specify which kinds of veggies you want.  I usually get Thai eggplant and green beans added to red curry (which comes with just meats and bamboo normally).  The effect of this $2 addition is that you get a container of curry that is literally twice as big as the normal order, with tons of veggies.  You can also add extra meat as desired for a similar charge.  Adding veggies means paying $10.99 for a 32oz red curry full of meat and delicious Thai veggies, which I consider a great deal.  Once I discovered this, my issues with their menu were permanently solved, as red curry is sort of an addiction for me and the lack of veggies was my only complaint with their curries. --Pad Thai: my main issue with their Pad Thai is that ordering takeout, there is no option for spice.  They make it *bland* for the Midwestern palate as a default. UGH! You have to specify that you want it with spice in the comments or by being very clear with the waitress, or it will be boring.  Just let them know you want it hotter.  I do wish they provided it with the traditional bean sprouts (they substitute shredded cabbage), but I understand why they don't (sprouts have a terrible reputation for food poisoning).  With Opart, the best menu items in our eyes are: Yum Neur beef salad, Tom Yum Gai/Tom Kha Gai, Yum Woon Sen, Tiger Cry (same beef as the Yum Neur salad, no veggies), Panang or Red Curry with extra veggies.   Opart is real Thai food, so expect that, and order accordingly.  Portions are sufficient but not enormous.  Pseudo-Chinese dishes are not as good as the more authentic Thai dishes. Also, they seem more accurate at takeout/delivery than in the restaurant.  It's usually super busy on Friday and Saturday nights and that may be part of why the in-house service seems to make mistakes more often than the people getting the takeout/delivery together.  There's usually one guy in charge of all the takeout in the restaurant, and that seems to keep those orders well organized, as it is always quick and only once have I had anything missing in my order (and it was only one box of rice, out of maybe 30 orders in the last two years). Still, the food keeps us coming back or ordering delivery again).

I've been here twice now and I can't say that it's my favorite.  the first time I came, it was around 4pm and i was the only one, along with my friend. I ordered a chicken pad thai and to my surprise it was very wet, sticky, and heavy. the flavor was there but it seemed microwaved from dinner service from the previous night. the second time, I had come with two more friends during dinner time. this time I ordered a chicken pad see ew and it was quite lovely. the noodles were cooked perfectly and the sauce was light. the only thing is that the broccoli was undercooked and extremely overwhelming. the prices are a bit higher than my usual sticky rice fare, so I would really only go when my friends want to. the waiters are a bit rude but that may have been because I am young, however that should not be an excuse, as I should be treated as equally as everyone else.

I enjoy this place very much... It's a typical ethnic food place and and low-key.  It tends to get very busy, so I suggest to get a reservation when possible.  They menu is extensive and both vegetarian and carnivore friendly.  This is a BYOB place... This being said, it's a very affordable and tasty food :)

We really loved our time at Opart Thai. They have the expertise, the experience, and the means to deliver a well-rounded meal. The food is in the top five for Thai in the Chicagoland area; however, because of the ambiance, service, and price, I'd say that they're the best! They have the space and decor to accommodate many diners at once. It feels ethnic - perhaps a hodgepodge of authentic artwork and statues mixed with kitsch and a little well-loved functionality. For example, the tables and chairs are functional but are neither out-dated nor trendy. The restaurant is divided into at least three intimate rooms, each seating about 15 guests. Opart Thai has a staff that are good at their jobs. They know the menu, Thai food, and they can deliver a pleasant meal. What I mean is that you can expect to be greeted promptly upon entering the restaurant, have questions thoroughly answered, get solid recommendations, and have a well-timed delivery of food that is quickly cleared when finished. This isn't fine dining, but it's solid. The food is delicious. We got several dishes where two were clear stand-outs: the Tiger Cry and a recommendation by the server: Basil Noodles with Shrimp. We're likely to go that route again since we had such luck with the server suggesting an authentic Thai dish of which the chef was particularly talented in creating.  The final glory of Opart Thai is that it is BYOB. We went with our wine guy Allen who is particularly adept at bringing wonderful libations. Since Opart Thai is well equipped to handle guests, we felt comfortable lingering over our meal, drinks, and conversation. Anyway - you know what they say about BYOB? It makes the bill much more affordable!

Being a huge fan of Thai food, and very much looking forward to a nice meal out before a fun concert at the Aragon Ballroom, my date and I ventured to Opart Thai due to its great reviews and close proximity to the concert venue.  The decor was cheesy and dated, but we could've easily looked past that if the food was delish. Sadly, we were disappointed.  We ordered:  *Thai Iced Tea *Spring Rolls  *Soup (loved the soup with chicken, mushrooms, lemongrass, and lime)  *Sweet and Sour Vegetables w/ Tofu (wanted red curry sauce, but no accommodation) *Pad Thai with Shrimp  Our appetizer and entrees were left half-eaten, despite showing up ravenous. Our soup - (chicken, mushrooms, lemongrass, and lime) was unique and good.  Otherwise, we left bummed, feeling like we were mislead by the raving reviews.  We've had better Thai many other places.  Sorry, Opart. Won't be going back...

This is our go to Thai place from the first time we had it delivered.  Why go elsewhere when they literally have amazing food? Their flavors are multilayered and complex with the right amount of heat which so other Thai places strive to master.  (And I have tried a good number of places).  I recommend the pad Thai ( the way it should be made), tiger cry (really tender meat), and the green curry (so fragrant).  So so glad this place exists!

Ever have one of those extra demanding weeks? How about after a holiday visit with family? I caught a cold. Then, in manly tradition, Handsome Boyfriend declared I was "not sick" proceeded to drink from every glass, eat from every plate and take bites from all the same cutlery- then he was suddenly far more "not sick" than I ever was.  This would be funny if I weren't swamped in deadlines, his business rocking in full seasonal demand and um, multiple family obligations colliding at the same time.  We have no time for sniffles.  When you are achy, cranky, tired it is time for curry. A good curry will warm you up, flush out the sniffles, provide nutrients and make you happy! I mean look at these pictures- doesn't that look perfectly rich, indulgent, spicy, creamy and delicious? It IS!  Tata the server was very sweet, helpful and gracious. We enjoyed the shrimp and vegetable red curry the most- his choice- I hope you get to try it on a cold night to let it restore and soothe you thoroughly.  It is the most delicious magic.

Ordered pick-up from Opart and loved it. Everything was still hot when we got home. We got the sampler appetizer, the Penang curry, shrimp pad Thai, and curry fried rice. A little too much food for two people. Everything was very good but I LOVE the Penang curry!

I've only been here once, and went by other's reviews. I can attest that the tiger cry is the  bomb.com , miang-sa wong was AMAZING (lots of different flavors and textures, very very impressed), and the egg drop soup was unexpected and different, without being too different. Had that great egg drop taste, with ground chicken in it, which really kicked it up a notch. YUM. Will be back.

Pretty good Thai food. I like the location, despite the fact that they are a few feet from the (western) brown line you don't really hear the trains.  The food is excellent make sure you can handle the spicy food because Thai spicy is really spicy. They have great soup options and the waiter has usually been very accommodating. My favorite thai dish is pad see ew, but I don't like it as much here. I prefer to have my chicken slices and rice noodles larger,  some people may like it though cause it's easy to scarf down.
I love this place. Opart Thai's peanut lovers chicken is my favorite. I always order delivery from here to my home and business. And I love eating at the location. It is BYOB...Works for me!

This is one of those times where I enjoyed only half my food, but I'm very excited to come back and redo the part I didn't like. This place is a nice, cozy, popular place. My friend and I got seated immediately at 7 p.m. on a Wednesday, but about 30 minutes later people were waiting for a table. We went to Provenance before for a bottle of wine, because why go to the creepy, overpriced liquor store? We started with the peanut sauce spring rolls, which I absolutely loved. I am not a tofu fan but loved this...obviously the delicious peanut sauce helped. And you'll think by the price it will be a small app, but it isn't. We didn't even finish it. Now for the meehh...I'm a curry fan. Every time I go to a Thai place I get curry, and I mostly get the panang curry. Someone else said it was great here, but I was really disappointed. First, the portion size is small. How small do you say? Small enough that they serve it in a rectangular dish instead of bowl. Second, you have to pay $1 for rice. For curry. I mean, I only eat Thai about once a week so maybe I'm not an expert, but I thought rice always came with curry. Third, it was just okay. I've certainly had better panang curry- my favorite is from Rainbow Thai, which is just down the street.  Either way, I enjoyed my time there. Our waiter was very nice and we didn't wait long for food. I'll just plan on trying a different entree next time.  As far as the best Thai in the area? Again, this is just on the curry, but I'd say Rainbow Thai for carryout, Namo for dine-in, and maybe Aroy Thai and Opart Thai for another dish.

I didn't know it could get any better - BUT IT CAN! This time around we ordered the Tom Yum Pla and Panang Curry with white rice - both medium spice - and man were they delish! I seriously haven't had a better dish at a Thai place yet! If you're into spicy food, then I strongly suggest ordering, at minimum, the hot level of spice. The medium is pretty mild. Final Verdict: YUM!

Just ate here again the other night.  I really want to give this place four stars, but just can't, it's not that good.  I do like the tiger cry, the pad Thai is not very good, the sole fish with hot chills was okay, the fried rice is boring.  I just don't get it?  Why do so many people think this place is good?  Average at best...

Oparts has been one of our family's favorite Thai restaurant for over a decade. Tonight, however, was an utter disappointment, to say the least. My husband and I brought our two young children out to dinner. Our kids were hungry, so they were already onto their second Chicken Satay skewer when I noticed that the middle portion of the chicken was still RAW. We quickly called the waiter and he confirmed that it was indeed raw and apologized. He asked if we wanted them to make us another plate of Chicken Satay, but we declined. He removed it from our bill, but I'm still shocked that they would serve a dish that's so carelessly made. I just hope we don't get food poisoning tonight.  We ordered our usual Tiger Cry, Beef Pad See Ew, Tofu Pad Thai, and Curry fried rice.  The beef from pad see ew was very dry and hard to chew, so we had to pick them all out. Pad Thai noodles were over cooked and soggy. The only good dish we had tonight was the Tiger Cry.  By the way, my husband told me (after we finished eating), that he saw a cockroach scurrying under our table and quickly stepped on it.  I'm sad to say, but we won't be coming back.
